Name: storage lesion
Description: The so-called storage lesion was described to be associated with immune-modulation

Name: Rh incompatibility
Description: Extravascular hemolysis, however, results from Rh incompatibility of red blood cells

Name: endothelial lesions
Description: Damage to the endothelium (endothelial lesions) might be the primary cause of hemolysis

Name: schistocytes
Description: During DIC, fibrin strands within the fibrin mesh formed could cut red blood cells, resulting in the formation of schistocytes

Name: schistocytosis
Description: Infusions of thrombin induce DIC accompanied with hemolysis and schistocytosis.

Name: fibrin deposition
Description: Fibrin deposition in the blood vessels as a result of DIC might contribute to red blood cell fragmentation and, in turn, hemolysis

Name: Hemolysate
Description: The product resulting from the lysis of red blood cells

Name: Impaired microcirculation
Description: Usually present as decreased microvascular blood flow, damage to endothelial cells and high vascular permeability.

Name: renal stasis
Description: Renal stasis causes hemolysis

Name: microvascular stasis
Description: Hemopexin prevents from hepatic microvascular stasis

Name: cytolysin
Description: Some pathogens are capable of causing hemolysis by cytolytic toxins

Name: ABO antibodies
Description: Most hemolytic transfusion reactions can be attributed to ABO antibodies

Name: heme-hemopexin complex
Description: Haemopexin transports haem away from the vessel wall to LRP1 on macrophages

Name: ABO-incompatible erythrocytes
Description: Incompatibility of transfused RBCs

Name: stored erythrocytes
Description: Red blood cells that have been separated for blood transfusion

Name: fibrin monomer cross-linking
Description: Factor XIII stabilizes clots by catalysing fibrin monomer cross-linking

Name: vaso-occlusive crisis
Description: Common painful complication of sickle cell anemia in adolescents and adults

Name: Platelet margination
Description: RBCs preferentially move down the center of blood vessel, causing margination of platelets

Name: macrophage M1 polarization
Description: NAC was able to prevent iron-induced M1 polarization

Name: shear stress
Description: When RBCs are damaged by high shear in continuous flow ventricular assist devices

Name: erythrocyte-platelet adhesion
Description: The RBC-platelet adhesive interaction may be important in pathological conditions associated with a high incidence of thrombosis

Name: erythrocyte-endothelium adhesion
Description: RBCs do not interact with endothelium but they become highly sticky under certain pathological conditions

Name: permeability of fibrin
Description: RBCs increases the lytic resistance and decreases the permeability of fibrin

Name: Labile iron
Description: Transferrin (Tf) saturation and, finally, accumulation of labile plasma iron (LPI)

Name: Blood Transfusion, Acute
Description: Following acute transfusion, the most common occurs during the processes of extravascular hemolysis

Name: Blood Transfusion, Chronic
Description: Conversely, chronic transfusions associated with b-thalassemia major and sickle cell disease

Name: oxidative reactions
Description: Hpx-hemin complex prevents oxidative reactions

Name: Heme cytotoxicity
Description: FtH protects different cell types from the cytotoxic effects  of heme

Name: heme-iron recycling
Description: Reticuloendothelial system (RES, spleen and liver) contribute to RBC clearance and subsequently promote heme-iron recycling through erythrophagocytosis

Name: nitric oxide consumption
Description: Plasma NO consumption was measured ex vivo as a surrogate for the NO-scavenging capacity of the plasma

Name: Nitric oxide scavenging
Description: Scavenging of NO is markedly reduced

Name: heme-NO species
Description: Heme-NO species are generated by reaction of nitrite with deoxyHb

Name: Cerebral Blood Flow
Description: Adaptive increase in cerebral blood flow has also been demonstrated in other models of anemia

Name: Renal Blood Flow, limited
Description: No or limited increases in renal blood flow are observed during acute hemodilution

Name: Anemia, subacute
Description: Both acute and subacute anemia are associated with renal tissue hypoxia

Name: Anemia, acute
Description: Both acute and subacute anemia are associated with renal tissue hypoxia

Name: Organ Dysfunction
Description: We observed a mild degree of plasma hypoxia could lead to organ injury

Name: Monocyte-platelet aggregation
Description: It was suggested that monocyte-platelet aggregates are a marker of platelet activation

Name: Pathogen Associated Molecular Pattern
Description: PAMPs (pathogen-associated molecular patterns) lead to the activation of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs)

Name: Thrombus
Description: One mechanism that may contribute to enhanced platelet thrombus formation is inhibition of the metalloprotease

Name: Erythrocytes, lysed
Description: In addition, lysed erythrocytes release arginase

Name: Atheromatous lesions
Description: Oxysterols and oxidation products of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) are present in human atheromatous lesions

Name: Atheroma lipid
Description: Heme treatment of the atheroma and its extracted lipid increased the amount of conjugated dienes

Name: Atheroma lipid cytotoxicity
Description: Have found that atheroma lipids when oxidized by heme are highly cytotoxic to human endothelial cells

Name: ferrihemoglobin
Description: Both ferro- and ferrihemoglobin induced the oxidative modification of atheromatous lesion lipids

Name: oxidative modification of atheroma lipid
Description: Both ferro- and ferrihemoglobin induced the oxidative modification of atheromatous lesion lipids

Name: Endothelial cytotoxicity
Description: Oxidative modification of LDL can cause endothelial cytotoxicity

Name: Endothelial dysfunction
Description: Lipids from atherosclerotic lesions were cytotoxic to endothelium

Name: ruptured complicated lesions
Description: Concentrations of iron, conjugated dienes and lipid hydroperoxides were elevated by about 2-fold in ruptured complicated lesions

Name: Oxidative damage
Description: A1M is a plasma and tissue protein with the capacity to bind free radicals and heme groups, and the capacity to repair oxidative damage by chemical reduction.

Name: Immunothrombosis
Description: Abnormal aggregation of erythrocytes under septic conditions may also contribute to immunothrombosis in sepsis.

Name: cytoskeletal reorganization
Description: HbFe4+ (20 mM), but not HbFe3+  or HbFe2+, induced cytoskeletal reorganization
